276. Jones, Ruth Elizabeth Mawby (Mrs. Arthur)
What did Eastern Canadian pioneers eat?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. A. James
Address: Box 1733, Duncan, B.C.
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? Sept. 7th, 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? East Haddon, Northampton
Where had you been living before that? 7 months at Brothers Bay
How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, Sugar, Salt, Rolled Oats, Dried Apples, Peaches, Raisins, Currants, Dried Peas & Navy Beans, Lentils, Baking Soda, Baking Powder, Rum, Syrup, Jam, Tea, Coffee, Cocoa, Butter, Lard, Onions, Rice, Paprika, Spices, Pepper

In what quantities did you buy it? Three Hundred lbs.

How much did you use graham flour? About a 1/4 each baking
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Answer: From the farm.

Butter? Answer: Yes

Did you make butter? Answer: Yes

What kind of cheese? Answer: Cottage

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early days? Answer: Bacon & Ham

How did you get fresh meat? Answer: From the farm

How did you preserve meat? Answer: In the spring & fall

How often did you get fresh meat? Answer: Weekly

Has there been a "beef ring" in your neighborhood?

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Answer: Yes

What kind? Answer: Chicken

For how long? Answer: About 10 years

What part did fish play in the family diet? Answer: Main course food during the winter

Was the fish fresh, canned, or salted? Answer: Canned salmon

Kind? Answer: Herring & Sardines

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? $1.5...

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
$1.25... Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes...
If not, where from? A neighbor who had settled earlier.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1912, Cabbage 1912, Carrots 1912, Onions 1912,
Turnips 1912, Beets 1912...

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 50 lbs...
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? By the box...
What weight? 25 lbs... How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes...
Also in bulk... What was the price of prunes? $2.00 each

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought or also made some.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes... wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown and yellow bar soap.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood, Poplar shavings.

Where did you get your fuel? From sleighs, horses, from no. 2. Later, from the river. 25 miles 3 day trip with oxen.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. Willows were always most welcome as they gave good heat; also we were very lucky when the men brought home a load of dry wood having found some trees that were dead. We bought the 1st ton of coal in 1914 to keep the fire burning during the night. Coal & wood are still used, many using coal oil & gasoline stoves during the summer months.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Enamel.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, we always had plenty of food.

Our first 20 acre crop of Wheat was frozen
it was threshed by flailing it on the kitchen floor.
After the first winter we had our own cow
& chickens which kept us supplied with
a fresh supply of Milk, Butter & eggs.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the month of March 1910.

Breakfast: Porridge, Red Biscuits, Bacon & Eggs, Toast or Jam, Coffee or Tea

Dinner: Meat, Potatoes, Bread & Butter, Cake

Supper: Pork & Beans, Biscuits, Bread & Butter

1910. Morning: Porridge, Bacon & Eggs, Toast or Jam, Coffee or Tea

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

19. Have you ever purchased or exchanged local produce? Give details.

1910. We always had plenty of food.

Our first 2-acre crop of Wheat was grown, it was threshed by hauling it on the kitchen floor. After the first winter we had our own cow & chickens which kept us supplied with a fresh supply of milk, Butter & Eggs.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Everything that was done we had to do for ourselves. Baking Bread, Cakes, Pies, Churning etc. The Pressure Cooker is I think the most outstanding difference.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still rely for the most part on our own produce.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Sorry & cannot fill in prices as my brothers did most of the shopping. Quite often we bought groceries by bulk from Eaton's or McDonald's. We did not go to town often but the neighbors would let others know when they were going so we would get the mail & groceries brought out. Quite often the women folk would not be in town more than once a year so that would be on sports day. I well remember the first sports day July 1911. 4 of us went to Senta & such a severe came up
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible). Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of preparation, etc.

We still rely for the most part on our own produce.

22. Plans and other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and acquiring foods in other places. Include plans in Western Canada.

Include problems of storage, shortages and other details. Use back of paper if more space is needed.

I cannot fill in prices as my brothers did most of the shopping. Quite often we bought groceries by hook from Eaton's or McDonald's. We did not go to town often but the neighbors would tell others know when they were going & we would get the mail & groceries throughout.

Quite often the women folk would not be in town more than once a year & that would be on afternoons. You'll remember the first snowstorm day July 1911. It was so warm to Semlac & such a severe storm came up.
we had to stay overnight getting home about
10 a.m. the next day. They had the storm too so
were not too worried though glad when we
finally arrived home.
